– Moves file fragments so they are contiguous
– Improves read and writing time

Selected Answer: B

Selected Answer: C
C. Disk Cleanup

Disk Cleanup helps to free up disk space on the hard drive by removing unnecessary files such as temporary files, system files, and recycle bin contents. By running Disk Cleanup, the technician can potentially improve the performance of the PC by clearing out unnecessary files that may be causing the slowdown.

Disk Defragmentation (option B) is useful for optimizing the layout of files on the disk, but it may not directly address the issue of slow loading programs and files if the primary concern is disk space rather than fragmentation.

Disk Management (option A) and Device Manager (option D) are not directly related to disk cleanup or optimizing disk performance. Disk Management is used for partitioning and formatting disks, while Device Manager is used for managing hardware devices.

Selected Answer: B
B. No need for disk clean up if there is adequate free space.

Selected Answer: C
The question say what do you do "first". Disk Cleanup comes before Disk defragment. So I am going with C

Disk Cleanup

questions.question_text: A desktop technician has received reports that a user's PC is slow to load programs and saved files. The technician investigates and discovers an older HDD with adequate free space. Which of the following should the technician use to alleviate the issue first?

choices.C: Deploy an ad-blocking extension to the browser.
choices.A: Scan the computer with the company-provided antivirus software.
choices.B: Install a new hard drive and clone the user's drive to it.
choices.E: Click the link in the messages to pay for virus removal.
choices.F: Perform a reset on the user's web browser.

questions.question_text: A user contacted the help desk to report pop-ups on a company workstation, indicating the computer has been infected with 137 viruses and payment is needed to remove them. The user thought the company-provided antivirus software would prevent this issue. The help desk ticket states that the user only receives these messages when first opening the web browser. Which of the following steps would MOST likely resolve the issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Its absoluly A and F. You shouldnt block the ads, you should remove them. Its almost certainly a proxy redirect so resteeing browser and running antivirus best solution.

comments.content: He thought the company provided anti - virus software. Therefore, does not know for sure if they have it or used it. So run an anti- virus software
Pop ups can be adware. And adware is still considered malware.
It didn't catch the malware in real time (active scan). but that doesn't mean a full system scan wouldn't find it.

the best first steps to resolve the issue would be scanning with antivirus software and resetting the browser, as they directly target the root cause of the pop-ups.

ONLY receives when opening the web browser plus the antivirus software you are suggesting to use is already stated to NOT be preventing the issue and would probably accomplish nothing. It is C and F, reinstall the browser to clear any issues with it and install an adblocker to get rid of unwanted popups.

Selected Answer: CF
Question is asked what is most likely to RESOLVE the issue. F remains a top recommendation because it directly targets the root cause (browser hijacking or unwanted extensions that are causing the pop-ups.).

C might be more immediately effective than scanning with the current antivirus software, given the scenario. This would prevent the pop-ups from appearing in the first place, especially if they're caused by malicious ads or scripts.

These steps directly address the issue and are likely to prevent further occurrences. Scanning with antivirus software is still valuable but might be secondary in resolving the immediate problem of pop-ups.

Selected Answer: AF
its A and F , the reason why the antivirus didnt work is because is a false alarm luring the person into paying the ad so as long as the antivirus is aware the computer is not effected is a simple AD pop up
AC screen for virus then block AD
Companies have strict protocols, therefore A-F would be a no brainer

A pop-up blocker would prevent pop-ups from appearing, but it won't remove the adware or malware causing this. I think the most appropriate action here is to A and F, since C won't remove the adware (it'll just prevent the pop-ups from showing).

Selected Answer: AC
While resetting the web browser can sometimes resolve issues related to browser settings or extensions, it may not address the underlying cause of the pop-up messages, which is likely malware or adware.

Therefore, scanning the computer with the antivirus software and deploying an ad-blocking extension to the browser are the most appropriate steps to take in resolving the issue.

I was originally CF but im changing my answer to AF because i feel like its common sense to always run the anti virus software in a situation like this.

i dont usually vote but i gotta for this one, you gotta run that antivirus, i wasnt sure whether c or f would be better for the second answer but i think resetting the browser after running the antivirus might do a bit better than using an ad blocker.

If the browser is infected, always check with a malware scan because a separate program (often marked on antivirus programs as a PUP) may be injecting the browser with the adware.
An ad-blocking program only targets the current site meaning it won't help against a PUP or a messed up browser config.

A and F. You scan as a best practice but the issue is notifications being pushed from web browsers.

Selected Answer: AC
To resolve the issue of pop-ups on a company workstation, the following steps should be taken:
1. Scan the computer with the company-provided antivirus software to detect and remove any malware or viruses that may be present on the system. This is the first step in resolving any security-related issues on a computer.

2. Deploy an ad-blocking extension to the browser to prevent pop-ups from appearing when browsing the web. Ad-blocking extensions can help prevent unwanted ads and pop-ups from appearing on a user’s screen, which can help reduce the risk of malware infections.

Selected Answer: CF
The question asks which options will most likely RESOLVE the issue. Scanning the system doesn't resolve the issue. Blocking the ads and resetting the web browser actually resolves the issue, whether it's efficient or not doesn't matter in this case.

Selected Answer: AF
Open your Windows Security settings. Select Virus & threat protection > Scan options. Select Windows Defender Offline scan, and then select Scan now
Persistent web page issues may be resolved by clearing your web browser's cache and cookies. If the issue continues, or you have other browser issues, you could also try resetting your browser to its default settings

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
The situation described in the help desk ticket is indicative of a form of malware known as "scareware" or "fake antivirus." Scareware attempts to trick users into thinking their computer is infected and extorts them into paying for removal, even though no real infection exists. To resolve this issue, the following steps would be appropriate:

A. Scan the computer with the company-provided antivirus software: Running a full system scan using the company-provided antivirus software is a necessary step to ensure that there is no actual malware on the system. The antivirus software should be able to detect and remove any threats if present.

C. Deploy an ad-blocking extension to the browser: The fact that the pop-ups only occur when opening the web browser indicates that the user might be encountering malicious ads or scripts. Installing an ad-blocking extension in the web browser can help prevent these unwanted pop-ups and reduce the risk of encountering malicious content.

Selected Answer: E
Its E.

A AND F ARE CORRECT
Deploying an ad-blocking extension can help prevent these types of pop-ups in the future, but by itself might not resolve the current problem if there's a PUP or malicious extension already installed.

The correct answer is CF
A doesn't hold water because the scareware requested payment for the 137 non existent viruses.

Selected Answer: AF
If user's company computer has pop-ups indicating 137 viruses & needs payments to remove them, user should scan the computer directly with company-provided antivirus software, & do a full reset on the user's web browser. This attack very likely came from a cross-site scripting certification attack, & is now on user's computer rather than hidden inside the browser notifications & site advertisements.

I think the focus on with Comptia is always try the simple things first and rule out the obvious - so i would run antivirus the reset browser. This may not work but it's the simplest and "most likely" to fix.

discussion.content:
A. Scan the computer with the company-provided antivirus software.
C. Deploy an ad-blocking extension to the browser.
A. Scanning the computer with the company-provided antivirus software is essential to detect and remove any potential malware or viruses causing the pop-up messages. Running a thorough scan will help identify and eliminate any malicious software on the workstation.

C. Deploying an ad-blocking extension to the web browser can prevent the pop-up messages from appearing in the first place. Ad-blocking extensions can block malicious advertisements and pop-ups, reducing the chances of encountering such fake messages.

Selected Answer: AC
A. Scan the computer with the company-provided antivirus software. C. Deploy an ad-blocking extension to the browser.
Scanning the computer with the company-provided antivirus software can detect and remove any viruses that may be causing the pop-ups. Deploying an ad-blocking extension to the browser can prevent these types of pop-up messages from appearing in the first place. Installing a new hard drive and cloning the user's drive to it is unnecessary and time-consuming. Uninstalling the company-provided antivirus software would leave the computer vulnerable to further infections. Clicking the link in the messages to pay for virus removal is not recommended as it is likely a scam. Performing a reset on the user's web browser may temporarily fix the issue, but it is not a long-term solution.

A. Scan the computer with the company-provided antivirus software and C. Deploy an ad-blocking extension to the browser would most likely resolve the issue. The pop-ups the user is experiencing are a common tactic used by malicious actors to scare users into purchasing fake antivirus software or paying for virus removal services. Scanning the computer with the company-provided antivirus software may help detect and remove any malware that is causing the pop-ups. Deploying an ad-blocking extension to the browser may help prevent the pop-ups from appearing in the first place. Installing a new hard drive and cloning the user's drive to it, uninstalling the company-provided antivirus software, and clicking the link in the messages to pay for virus removal are not recommended steps and may even worsen the issue. Performing a reset on the user's web browser may be a possible solution, but it would only be effective if the browser is the source of the issue.

Selected Answer: D
D. Roll back updates.

If certain locally attached devices stopped working after a Windows update, and a reboot did not resolve the issue, the technician should consider rolling back the updates. Rolling back updates involves reverting the system to a previous state before the problematic updates were installed.

questions.question_text: An employee calls the help desk regarding an issue with a laptop PC. After a Windows update, the user can no longer use certain locally attached devices, and a reboot has not fixed the issue. Which of the following should the technician perform to fix the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The Server Message Block (SMB) protocol is a network file sharing protocol that allows applications on a computer to read and write to files and to request services from server programs in a computer network

SMB is a network file sharing protocol that is widely supported by operating systems like Windows, macOS, and Linux.
It allows users to access and share files over a network, making it a suitable choice for file transfers.
It's a common protocol built into most workstations, so no additional software or configuration is typically required.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to transfer a file to a user's workstation. Which of the following would best accomplish this task utilizing the workstation's built-in protocols?
Which of the following is most likely used to run .vbs files on Windows devices?

comments.content:
Cscript.exe is a Windows console-based script host that's part of the Windows Script Host module. It's used to start scripts so they can run in a command-line environment.
Here are some things to know about cscript.exe: 
 
Output: Cscript sends its output to the command window it was started in, while WScript generates windowed output. 
 
File extensions: Windows script files often have the following extensions: .wsf, .vbs, .js. 
 
Registering as default script host: To register cscript as the default script host for a file type, double-click a script file with an unknown extension, select Open With, then cscript, and finally Always use this program to open this file type.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Cscript.exe is the main executable for Windows Script Host (WSH). It is essentially the command-line version of the WSH service and facilitates command-line options for setting up script properties. With Cscript, scripts can be run automatically or by simply typing the name of the script file inside the command prompt.

Selected Answer: C
program used to run .vbs (VBScript) files on Windows devices is C. cscript.exe. This is a command-line version of the Windows Script Host that provides command-line options for setting script properties. The other options are not primarily used for running .vbs files:

A. winmgmt.exe is the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) service and is not used for running .vbs files.
B. powershell.exe is the Windows PowerShell command line shell, a scripting language from Microsoft built on .NET Framework.
D. explorer.exe is the user shell, which we see as the familiar taskbar, desktop, and other user interface features. This process isn’t used to run scripts.

Selected Answer: C
C. cscript.exe

.vbs files (VBScript files) are typically executed using the Windows Script Host (WSH), and one of the common ways to run VBScript files is through the command-line script host tool, cscript.exe. This tool is designed to run scripts in command-line mode and provides a way to execute VBScript code.
